text: A Lord of Undeath's minions do not suffer exhaustion, they can walk for leagues and never suffer.
Speak these words and watch the landscape around you twist and crack, corrupted by his name alone.
More valuable than gold or jewels, the greatest spoils of war are the lifeforces that own them.
Once slain in battle, the foe belongs to the Undead Lord, and will rise again, eager to serve.
The corrupting influence of Dark Magic emanates from this lord like a beacon to all shadowy and otherworldy beings.
All creatures that once were living, then were dead, but now are neither, rise to answer the call of the Lord of Undeath
By which the Undead armies of Nagash may remain deathless, undying and forever hungry for slaughter.
To the victor, the spoils. All of them. Always.
They stand watch over the land, ever living, ever vigilant waiting for opportunistic agents who dare to strike.
This Lord's many deeds - both on and off the battlefield - have brought them renown among their allies and made them feared by their enemies.
Beware those who sail under the black flag - they give no quarter and never, ever give up the chase.
Such a beast is all but impossible to destroy - an immortal horror doomed to haunt eternity!

In that dread desert, beneath the moon's pale gaze, dead men walk. They haunt the shifting dunes of the breathless, windless night, brandish weapons of bronze in mocking challenge and bitter resentment of the life they no longer possess. And sometimes, in ghastly dry voices, like the rustling of sun-baked reeds, they whisper the one word they remember from life. The name of the one who cursed them to their existence, more than death but less than life. They whisper the name, Nagash...
More valuable than gold or jewels, the greatest spoils of war are the lifeforces that own them.
Once slain in battle, the foe belongs to the Undead Lord, and will rise again, eager to serve.
The corrupting influence of Dark Magic emanates from this lord like a beacon to all shadowy and otherworldy beings.
All creatures that once were living, then were dead, but now are neither, rise to answer the call of the Lord of Undeath
By which the Undead armies of Nagash may remain deathless, undying and forever hungry for slaughter.
To the victor, the spoils. All of them. Always.
They stand watch over the land, ever living, ever vigilant waiting for opportunistic agents who dare to strike.
Those who walk the lands of the dead soon meet death, then undeath.

They haunt the shifting dunes of the breathless, windless night, brandish weapons of bronze in mocking challenge and bitter resentment of the life they no longer possess. And sometimes, in ghastly dry voices, like the rustling of sun-baked reeds, they whisper the one word they remember from life. To the victor, the spoils. All of them. Always.
They stand watch over the land, ever living, ever vigilant waiting for opportunistic agents who dare to strike.
Those who walk the lands of the dead soon meet death, then undeath.

The Supreme Lord of Undeath, the ultimate personification of death and the undead, an ancient, evil being who seeks to conquer this cruel, chaotic world and bring about an age of undeath that will rule for all eternity.
Rise! The Undying King commands you! Come to me!

There will be no escape, no blessed oblivion. I can end your life as easily as I can extinguish a candle, and before your corpse is cold, I can reach out and grasp your soul. You will be my slave for all eternity, and I shall laugh at the depths of your pain. Such is the power of Nagash.
The dead do not squabble as this land’s rulers do. The dead do not fight one another. The dead have no desires, no petty jealousies or ambitions. A world of the dead is a world at peace...
See the fate of all flesh and know despair!

Nagash's armour is forged from an alloy of lead and meteoric iron. Over the millennia the armour has fused itself with his body, so it may only be worn by Nagash. Obviously, the armour does not prevent him casting spells.
Mortis – The Great Blade of Death

Mortis is a huge magic sword that crackles with unearthly power. The blade was forged and enchanted by Nagash himself and no-one else may use it. The sword increases his already considerable strength, and wounds caused by the sword can be used to heal Nagash himself.

Nagash was the first and greatest of all the Necromancers, and he created almost all of the spells that allow these followers of the dark arts to raise and control the Undead. The secrets of his magical spells are recorded in nine massive tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash. Each book contains the secrets of one of Nagash's Necromantic spells.
The Staff of Power was created by Nagash to allow him to store the additional power he needed to carry out his most arcane and dangerous magical spells.

The Crown of Sorcery sometimes known as the Crown of Nagash is a magical crown/circlet forged by the great Necromancer Nagash around -1300 IC in his fortress of Nagashizzar in Cripple Peak. The crown is infused with part of Nagash's malicious spirit, partially holding his spirit to the mortal world, and exerts a corrupting influence on anyone who wears it.
Although not as numerous as Settra's grand army, Arkhan's Undead legions are bolstered by the Liche King's unparalleled necromantic dexterity.
The first and most loyal of the Great Necromancer's followers will stand at his side once again. So it is written…
If there's duty to be paid, rest assured that this one will find a way around it.
Fire, to destroy all that you have done; fire, to end all you've become.
Some seafarers appear to have been born for the role.
By which death is expertly dealt, assuming it doesn't blow your hand off in the process!
His crimes are without number and his villainy without end… behold the Pirate King!
No longer a plaything of Gods, take their given many gifts, including formidable fighting skills and strike at them!
Having forever escaped the shackles of mortality, with Nagash's assistance, Krell will never stop - he'll keep coming back until they're all *very* dead!

Nagash's great champion, Krell, a raging spirit within ancient bones, clad in dark enchanted armour. A Berserker tactician with the power of immortality. Victory is certain with this herald of slaughter.
Woe to the conquered, in a world where "might makes right" be mighty enough to conquer death.
Krell beat death long before even Nagash had found him, appearing as a Spectral Executioner offering battle to any who'd face him slaying all who matched blades with the ghost.

So many skulls did Krell lay at Khorne's feet, so much blood did he spill in his name. Old habits die hard, yet it is not Khorne's Skull Throne that piles ever higher it's the Supreme Lord of Undeath's.
When Krell perished there was no dark trumpet call, no chariot of brass to bear his spirit to an eternity of battle. There was just the cold, wet hillside and the cheering of his foes.
Commander of the Doomed Legion, raised by Nagash as Krell's personal minions, they serve in the forefront of Nagash's battles refusing to give ground, enduring, undying.
Krell hears Nagash's ghostly voice with a clarity matched by none save Arkhan the Black, and he obey's his master without hesitation. Where Krell walks, it is Nagash's will that is done.
If anything, this one has an even greater lust for life than they did before their death.

One hundred and thirty-six of her followers have raised armies, fleets and beasts to hurl themselves against my walls. They come from north, east, south. sea, sky and sand, from the jungles and the mountains too. They pour forth in a limitless tide and they are broken on my walls.
Ancient, powerful, beautiful, seductive and cunning, traits that give the Queen of Mysteries advantage on the battlefied with both blade and tongue.

Queen of Lahmia and First of the Vampires, Neferata distiled an Elixer of Life which cursed her for all eternity. Neferata and her court became stricken by an unquenchable thirst for mortal blood. Lahmia became the birthplace of the Vampires.
You are a greater fool than even I believed, and never shall you join my kin. We are guests at the ultimate masquerade, and your kind is simply not invited.
Behind every great man is a great woman. And behind those great women is me.
Created by the Arch-Necromancer, the staff harnesses Dark Magic from deep within the accursed Black Pyramid.
The sword burns away the flesh of Arkhan's victims, leaving nothing but a charred skeleton, bound to the Liche King's dark will for all eternity.
This accursed blade drinks deep of its victim's blood, restoring vigour and strength to the one who brandishes it.
An ancestral ring, set with a gem of deep, sanguine claret that has granted the von Carsteins everlasting Undeath.
The Lord of the von Carsteins exudes a distracting and sensational air, giving all before him pause.
It is well known that Lustrian gold is enchanted with all manner of esoteric properties; Harkon thinks it will restore his fractured mind!
This evil weapon not only fills its wielder with an unholy energy but also entraps the souls of those it cleaves, binding their jleshless remains in servitude.

The passage of the ages has strengthened rather than weakened this elaborate Chaos plate armour. Such is the aura of entropy that surrounds it that it has the power to decay the magic of enemy weapons in an instant.
When the Black Axe of Krell bites into flesh, it leaves behind jagged shards that swiftly eat their way into the victim's heart.
Akmet-kar, the Dagger of Jet whose cursed edge screams with the death agonies of innocents and saps the vitality and fighting spirit of its victims.
Aken-seth, the Staff of Pain, whose enchantments add crippling agonies to any sorceries she wields.
A product of twisted sorcery, this construct fu ses with the wearer, giving him tremendous endurance.
Whenever this blade tastes blood, its wielder seems to exert greater control over the vvtnds of Magic.
The life essence of many wretched, innocent smallfolk ensures that those who drink from this cursed cup thrive with newfound power.
To me, my winged steed of bone and flesh; let us fly and remake the world together!
The most impressive Nightmares are those reared on fresh blood. Such noble monstrosities are worthy mounts.

The dread abyssal ridden by Arkhan the Black was known to myth as Razarak. Whilst other dread abyssals scoured the depths of the Underworld, Razarak always sought lofty perches from which to track its prey. Such behavior was well-suited to its duties, for treachery is best judged from on high.

The dread abyssal ridden by Mannfred von Carstein was known to myth as Ashigaroth. Now reborn as a creature of chill bone in the mortal world, Ashigaroth hunts the living as readily as it ever did the dead, galloping through the skies to follow the spirit-spoor of prey.

The dread abyssal ridden by Neferata was known to myth as Nagadron. So voracious is Nagadron that it needs little goading to feast upon other prey, and gorges itself upon the living as eagerly as it did the souls of the dead.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
The pride of Nehekharan armies, impacting enemy lines with bone-shattering force and grinding the corpses beneath their heavy wheels.
Mannfred can ride an armoured steed of defiled flesh and bone; such an abominable horse is known as a 'Nightmare'.
Neferata can ride an armoured steed of defiled flesh and bone; such an abominable horse is known as a 'Nightmare'.
Harkon's personal mount is a dreadful thing indeed - a Terrorgheist with a piercing, banshee-like shriek that has the power to stun any who hear it.

*Insert Big Bone Daddy Autobiography here* [TEMP] Nagash, known by many names such as the Great Necromancer, the Great Betrayer, the Usurper, the Undying King, the Lord of Undead, He Who Shall Not Be Named or simply Bone Daddy.
A gift of knowledge from a single page of one of the nine books of nagash, a taste of power to sate their greed and ensure eternal loyalty.

This one is no apprentice in the black arts but a master of Necromancy and Dark Magic.
